content.definition: Pathology affecting the axillary artery, including aneurysm (often post-traumatic or from crutch use), thrombosis, embolism, and trauma. The axillary artery extends from the lateral border of the first rib to the lower border of teres major, where it becomes the brachial artery.

anatomy.first_part: Medial to pectoralis minor (1 branch: supreme thoracic)
anatomy.second_part: Behind pectoralis minor (2 branches: thoracoacromial, lateral thoracic)
anatomy.third_part: Lateral to pectoralis minor (3 branches: subscapular, anterior/posterior circumflex humeral)

clinical_pearls: Crutch palsy: compression causes both artery and brachial plexus injury
Baseball pitcher: repetitive overhead throwing causes aneurysm
Axillary artery injury complicates 5% of anterior shoulder dislocations
Rich collateral network around shoulder protects against ischemia
Axillary exposure via deltopectoral or infraclavicular approach

learning_objectives: Describe axillary artery anatomy and branch pattern
Understand treatment options for axillary aneurysm
